item.dc:creator: fillthevoid1
item.content:encoded:
About us

We envision a world where we can awaken true essence of womanhood and motherhood in Islam. We are trying to create educational content for Muslim women to connect her to purpose in life according to Islamic teachings, so that she can break free from indoctrinated ideas such as feminism, originating from Liberalism that conflict with Islam. Fostering a healthy understanding on self-awareness and the correct way to seek her rights. We aim to spread awareness on mental health and cultural issues, and building understanding that religion and culture are not the same.

item.title: Feminism & Islam
item.dc:creator: fillthevoid1
item.content:encoded:
Are feminism and Islam 180 degrees apart? Is there no base to feminist demands? Is everything a clash between liberalism and religion? Does Islam really suppress women and not give them rights and freedom?

There are surely quite a few similarities between feminism and what the Islam teaches. Let's review a couple of them first:

1) Prophet said :''The best of you are those who are best to their women'' (Sunan al-tirmidhi)

Thus a man's character is judged by his conduct towards women (domestic violence is unacceptable)

Give her food when you take food, clothe her when you clothe yourself, do not revile her face, and do not beat her (Sunan Abi dawud 2143)

2)Forced marriages are not allowed in Islam as mentioned in Quran 4:19

3)Prophet used to do house chores and most of his work by himself.

4)Women are not bound to work and men should provide for her

5)Woman is entitled to man's property and money whereas man is not entitled to hers.

Thus himself, home, family, kids are a part of a man's duty as they are a woman's. There are a few boundaries and role divisions to it according to Islam only. Since there is no difference in such and other aspects, why go under a new banner?

To all the lovely women out there, please know your worth.

If we call ourselves open-minded then we should open up our minds a little to educate ourselves about what Allah says and we shouldn't just walk blindly behind some misguided people who are unaware that they are merely disobeying Allah.

Women are unaware of the fact that ''Aurat march'' has broken the limits of Allah.Feminists themselves are often confused about what they stand for and the direction they need comes from the Qur'an. Islam gives women more rights and freedom than any other religion and as a proof, I have compiled some ayahs and their interpretation as an answer to all the Aurat march placards:

Firstly, when i say the Shahadah ''La ilaha ila la muhammad ur rasullalah' By this I declare that I submit myself to Allah alone and the last prophet Muhammad(saw).This means I should follow what is written in the Quran and not ask for rights which are outside the teachings of it or neither should I deny the verses ,as there is no room for argument left.

''If you are in any doubt whether it is We Who have revealed this Book to Our servant, then produce just a surah like it, and call all your supporters and seek in it the support of all others save Allah. Accomplish this if you are truthful.

But if you fail to do this; and you will most certainly fail; then have fear of the Fire whose fuel is men and stones and which has been prepared for those who deny the Truth.'' Ayat 23,24 Al Baqarah.

A woman's status in society before the advent of Islam was literally nothing; they were treated like property and were buried alive. Allah has elevated the status of the woman through Islam. He has given her all the rights she would need to feel empowered and accepted in society.

Then why do you need equality? Then why patriarchy ka janazah?

In Surah Nisa Verse 34(interpretation) the man is responsible for the woman, and he is her maintainer, caretaker and leader who disciplines her if she deviates because men excel over women and are better than them for certain tasks.
This is why Prophethood was exclusive of men, as well as other important positions of leadership.

One crucial, unequivocal verse in the Qur’an lays the ground for the concept of equality between men and women:

Allah says in Quran 9:71 “The believers, men and women, are allies (awliya) of one another. They enjoin the ‘common good’ (al ma‘ruf) and forbid the bad (al munkar), they observe prayers (salat) and give charitable alms (zakat) and obey God and his Prophet”

Then why do you need lgbt rights?

And (remember) Lut: behold, he said to his people: “You do commit lewdness, such as no people in Creation (ever) committed before you. Do you indeed approach men, and cut off the highway?- and practise wickedness (even) in your councils?” But his people gave no answer but this: they said: “Bring us the Wrath of Allah if thou tellest the truth.” (Surat al-Ankaboot: 28-29) Allah destroyed them;he tells us this in Surah Al Araaf(80-84)

Then why ask for consent?

When Allah has allowed simple method of nikkah and for the fornicator he has the punishment of lashes in Surah Nur

Then why do you say that haya should be in the eye of beholder only and not in your dressing?

Although there are many benefits of Hijab, it is first and foremost a commandment from God. Therefore, wearing it is an act of faith and obedience to The Creator, as mentioned in the Quran:

"Tell the believing women to draw their outer garments around them (when they go out or are among men)." Quran 33:59

The Hadeeth was reported by Muslim in Sahih from Abu Mousa Al-Ash'ari.He said: “The Prophet stood among us and told us five things. He said: “Verily, Allah, the Exalted and Mighty, does not sleep and it does not befit Him to sleep. He lowers the scale and lifts it. The deeds of the night are taken up to Him before the deeds of the day, and the deeds of the day [are taken up to Him] before the deeds of the night. His veil is the light - in the narration of Abu Bakr (instead of the word" light") it is fire. If he reveals it, the splendor of His Countenance would burn His creation as far as His sight reaches.”

SubhanAllah Allah ﷻ has a veil and He chooses a veil for women.

How amazing it is for Him to choose for women what He has for Himself.

I am sorry but Aurat march has not helped any single person out there and has only used a few oppressed women as a prop instead. It has introduced some rather troubling western ideas to the table and offended quite a lot of sentiments. The only outcry I hear is of gender roles and equality but the real issues of underprivileged women remain untouched.

We do not need to get the label of a ''Feminist'' but we need to work on getting the label of ''Mu'min'' which we can.

Just look into the Qur'an and there is a lot more for women in it which will make you fall in love with it, and once you start reading, understanding and following Islam, the inner satisfaction and contentment that you'll feel is something which is beyond measure.

Do not rely on incomplete sources and do not think you can learn the entire deen by watching some YouTube video or googling.

We should fear Allah and not lead astray other unshaped minds.

Jazakillah Khair.💗
item.excerpt:encoded: In the ever-evolving world, the art of forging genuine connections remains timeless. Whether it’s with colleagues, clients, or partners, establishing a genuine rapport paves the way for collaborative success.

item.title: Real Hijab & Haya
item.dc:creator: fillthevoid1
item.content:encoded:
WHAT IS HAYAA?

Hayaa is a general term for modesty or shyness and is often associated with women and their outer covering. However it is a broader term for having deep rooted sense of shame from Allah and hesitation in sinning.

“Haya (modesty) and Iman (faith) are two that go together. If one is lifted, the other is also lifted.” (Recorded by al-Hakim)

Prophet Muhammad SAW said:

الحياء = Hayaa = Life

Hayaa is derived from Arabic word meaning, life. Arabs would equate it with being alive.

We should possess both inner and outer modesty. This is reflected in behavior, speech, and appearance, and includes being mindful of God at all times. Hayaa is not about the outer covering only. Many times you would see hijabis or men with beard with no or little shyness whereas girls without hijab/niqab or boys without beard being more modest in character. Hayaa is to be applied in every aspect of life.

We should possess both inner and outer modesty. This is reflected in behavior, speech, and appearance, and includes being mindful of God at all times.

Hayaa is not about the outer covering only. Many times you would see hijabis or men with beard with no or little shyness whereas girls without hijab/niqab or boys without beard being more modest in character. Hayaa is to be applied in every aspect of life.

This can be also called fitrah based hayaa as it is an innate attribute given to us by Allah SWT. It is triggered by awrah being exposed, nakedness. Feeling uneasy at which is something disgraceful or shameful.

INSTINCTUAL HAYAA

HOW IS IT UNDER ATTACK?

Desensitization resulting from continuous exposure to inappropriate content on social media. Normalization of semi-naked individuals in TV ads and billboards. Influence from exposure to new ideas, including LGBTQ+ rights and "my body, my choice," as part of larger brainwashing agendas.

FAITH BASED HAYAA

This prevents a Muslim from committing the forbidden out of fear of Allah. Dhū al-Nūn al-Miṣri (d. 859) defines the latter as “finding an intimidation and sadness in the heart due to the acts you have done before your Lord.”

HOW IS IT UNDER ATTACK?

Faith based hayaa can become to grow as natural as fitrah based, people can be deconditioned by all notions of haya as foreign and oppressive. They can pollute your original haya and Islam does not assume that it will remain intact but it can be rehabilitated once compromised. Most of it is from what we are consuming online and we are tempted to sin.

This is also a type of hayaa which is to be done in private. When you are alone in your bedroom and you have access to internet but you fear Allah and refrain from any type of private sins. Even if you commit them privately, you should not speak of your or other people’s sins publicly.

Hayaa from oneself

Prophet Muhammad SAW said: “I certainly know people of my ummah who will come on the Day of Resurrection with good deeds like the mountains of Tihaamah, but Allah will make them like scattered dust.” Thawbaan said: O Messenger of Allah, describe them to us and tell us more, so that we will not become of them unknowingly. He said: “They are your brothers and from your people, worshipping at night as you do, but they will be people who, when they are alone, transgress the sacred limits of Allah.” Classed as saheeh by al-Albaani in Saheeh Ibn Maajah.

item.title: Rights of Women
item.dc:creator: fillthevoid1
item.content:encoded:
#1 Inheritance

Islamic inheritance law, as ordained in the Qur'an & specifically detailed in Surah An-Nisa, is designed for equitable asset distribution. A common perception is that women inherit less than men, often receiving half of what a man would. However, this simplification overlooks the law's nuanced nature & its integration within the broader Islamic social and familial framework. In reality, there are four distinct cases concerning women's inheritance: they might receive the same as men, more, less, or an exclusive share when men receive none. Contextually, men have broader financial obligations: they are solely responsible for alimony (nafaqa) and must provide for their family from their income and inheritance, whereas women are not obligated to do so. Men also bear exclusive responsibilities like the bride gift (Mahr) at marriage and financial compensations in certain legal scenarios like negligent homicide. Consequently, while women might appear "disadvantaged" in inheritance, they are exempt from these financial burdens. Their financial obligation is primarily limited to Zakat, the obligatory charity.

#2 Marriage

In Islamic marriage, both the bride and groom are given equal importance, ensuring the validity of the union through mutual consent. This valid marriage establishes mutual inheritance rights, entitling the wife to her dower and maintenance. However, marriage doesn’t give the husband control over the wife’s personal autonomy or her property beyond legal limits. Islam empowers women with the freedom to choose their life partners, free from coercion by family or guardians.. In Islam, a marriage conducted without the consent of the girl is considered null and void, and such a union is thus deemed unlawful.

#3 Dower

In Islam, the dower is a mandatory financial security for women in marriage, symbolizing respect and not to be viewed as a purchase price for marriage. The Holy Quran mandates husbands to give their wives their dower freely, and wives have the right to waive a part of it if they choose. It is a debt that the husband owes to the wife, which she can demand at any time. The dower can be prompt or deferred and is payable in cash or kind. It's determined by considering factors like the social status of the wife's family, the husband's financial condition, and the wife's personal qualifications. This dower, a bridal gift, is integral to the marriage contract in Islamic law, ensuring the wife's financial security. If unsettled at the time of marriage, the wife is still entitled to a proper dower. Under Islamic teachings, failure to pay the dower equates to a serious religious breach and a legal issue.

#4 Maintenance

Maintenance also known as nafqah, what the husband must do is spend on his wife on a reasonable basis, which includes the costs of accommodation, food, drink and clothing, according to scholarly consensus, & includes medical treatment and medicine according to the more correct opinion. With regard to accommodation, that is because Allah, may He be exalted, says: “Lodge them (the divorced women) where you dwell, according to your means, and do not treat them in such a harmful way that they be obliged to leave” [at-Talaaq 65:6]. If this refers to one who is divorced, then it is more applicable to one who is not divorced. With regard to food, drink and clothing, that is because Allah, says: “but the father of the child shall bear the cost of the mother’s food and clothing on a reasonable basis” [al-Baqarah 2:233]. And the Prophet Muhammad SAW said: “Their rights over you are that you should provide for them and clothe them on a reasonable basis.” Muslim (1218).

It was narrated that Mu‘aawiyah al-Qushayri said: I said: O Messenger of Allah, what are the rights of the wife of one of us over him? He said: “That you should feed her as you feed yourself, clothe her as you clothe yourself, not strike her on the face or curse her, and not forsake her except in the house (as a form of discipline).” Al-Bukhaari (55) & Muslim (1002) narrated from Abu Mas‘ood al-Badri RA that the Prophet Muhammad SAW said: “If a man spends on his family, seeking reward for that with Allah, then it will be counted as an act of charity on his part.” Husband should understand the virtue of being generous towards his dependents, and treating his family kindly, and should understand that whatever he spends on his wife, he will be rewarded for it, for giving gifts increases love. So if he is well off, he should not refuse to give her this allowance, especially if she does not have any other source of income.

#5 Seperate Accomodation

The wife has the right to live in separate accommodation with her husband and children, and not to share it with anyone, whether it is a father, a mother or a relative. This is the view of most of the Hanafi, Shaafa’i and Hanbali fuqaha’. Shaykh al-Islam Ibn Taymiyah favoured the view that if the husband is poor or unable to provide separate accommodation for his wife, she does not have the right to ask for something he is unable to give. Rather she should bear it with patience until Allaah gives him the means. Separate accommodation is the wife’s right, even if she did not stipulate it in the marriage contract, and she has the right to ask for it later, and she is not regarded as being wilfully defiant because of that. The commonly held view among some people, that this is creating division among siblings, is not true, because this is a shar’i right of the wife, and it serves the interests of both spouses, because it prevents free mixing & guards them against looking at things that are not permissible. It is unfortunate that in many joint family homes, a man may look at his brother’s wife, and they may shake hands or be alone together, which may lead to jealousy, envy, disputes and separation. There may also be arguments because of the children.

Undoubtedly a man is a stranger (non-mahram) to his brother’s wife, so it is not permissible for him to shake hands with her or be alone with her, look at her or talk to her unnecessarily. If a woman observes hijab or pardah in front of husband’s brothers. It maybe bothersome for her to maintain it while cooking or doing house chores. She might not be fully comfortable. These are real situations and real problems which needs to be addressed. I would also like to respectfully add, that if you have a right to do something firstly its very important how you seek it, and secondly having a certain right does not mean you have to always exercise it. Understanding the circumstances and your home environment is very important. Above it all, it‘s the man‘s duty and responsibility to make sure that his wife feels comfortable, help sets boundaries with in laws and if she observes pardah OR he asks her to do hijab/niqab to which she obeys then she should be ensured complete privacy and in-laws should also respect that. This is really an untouched topic but joint families have proven to be cause of divorce, family politics, and mental issues in women especially. Typical households think a woman is to serve their family, and is not treated the same way as they would want their daughters to be treated. She leaves her house, and women by nature are delicate, sensitive, concerned about their security and privacy. Even if men cant seem to provide it all, their positive behaviour and treatment would mean the world to her. Men really need to know how to take stand for their wives. Pakistani or Asian Culture revolves around family drama because the primary foundation, deen is lacking in each individual. If it’s a woman she does not know how to seek her rights, If its a man, he does not know how to treat or deal with the situation, basically take a stand or if it’s other family members they’ll just add up more fire.

Matter of witnesses

With regard to the misconception many have that witness of two women being equal to the testimony of one man. Allaah has mentioned the wisdom behind specifying the number of two as being that a woman may forget or get confused, so the other woman can remind her, as He said: “…And get two witnesses out of your own men. And if there are not two men (available), then a man and two women, such as you agree for witnesses, so that if one of them (two women) errs, the other can remind her…” [al-Baqarah 2:282 – interpretation of the meaning] Scholars commented that this in no way means to belittle women or state that they are forgetful rather it is in accordance to hormonal issues, menstruation, pregnancy or post-partum phase women go through due to which they tend to be forgetful or likely to err.

Islam dignifies women in various roles – as mothers, daughters, sisters, and wives – contrasting sharply with their treatment during the Jahiliyyah era, where they were buried alive, mistreated and humiliated. Mothers are highly esteemed, with Paradise said to be at their feet, emphasizing their pivotal role in Islamic society. Daughters are cherished, and raising them well is considered a pathway to great reward. Sisters and aunts are honored, with Islam emphasizing the importance of kinship ties. Despite the immense respect and rights Islam has accorded to women since its inception over 1425 years ago, misconceptions persist among some Muslim women today, often stemming from a lack of deep understanding of the religion and its wisdom. In reality, Islam's approach seeks to create a balance; while men are tasked with the responsibility of providing for and caring for their families, women are afforded a respected status, with obedience expected within the framework of mutual respect and rights.

However, it's important for women to seek their rights practically within the Islamic context, as the core definition of ‘rights’ in Islam differ from Western interpretations. These rights should not be just about demands; rather one should also focus fulfilling their own obligations. The emphasis should be on awareness on the rights Islam gives and adopting a practical route to seek rights, rather than going out on roads chanting and dancing for rights. Advocating for women's rights should be conducted in a disciplined and serious way, not as a form of entertainment or mockery. Islamic law provides women with a simplified path to Paradise, yet they are seen more in number in Jahanum because of actions like ingratitude to husbands, gossip, and backbiting. The women's rights movement has an extensive history, but it is currently overshadowed by harmful Western ideologies that create chaos and confusion. There is a hidden agenda, funded by the West alongside visible, ruthless physical bombing and violence, also aimed at morally corrupting Muslims—a danger to which we remain oblivious (Gaafil). Currently, we see individuals posing as 'religious speakers,' yet they contradict Islamic teachings and distort Quranic verses for their own benefit. Their objective is to divert women into careerism and rights activism under the pretext of empowerment, leading to a morally corrupt generation. These actions also promote behaviors like same-sex relations, extramarital and premarital affairs, and abortion, couched in the rhetoric of 'my body, my choice,' to avoid the responsibilities of motherhood. They aim to strip away the essence of womanhood. This reflects the grave warning of Salahuddin Ayyubi: "In a nation you wish to destroy, spread immorality and adultery."
item.excerpt:encoded: Every business has a unique potential waiting to be tapped. Recognizing the keys to unlock this growth can set an enterprise on the path to unprecedented success.

item.title: Essence of Motherhood
item.dc:creator: fillthevoid1
item.content:encoded:
#motherhood #mentalhealth

In Gen-Z era, we are observing the narrative pushed to avoid the responsibilities of motherhood. They aim to strip away the essence of womanhood. Every woman on earth marries and has kids but what sets a Muslim woman apart? Setting the right ideology before she conceives or even gets married. One of her main aim should be tarbiyah of her children in an excellent manner so they can become 'Coolness of her eyes' as well as primarily serve to the mission of Islam. Today, we don't have a single gutsy leader standing up for Gaza. Why? Real Motherhood died. Real Womanhood expired. Feminism is brought to life.

More Coming Soon...

item.excerpt:encoded: What fosters effective teamwork? It’s not just about grouping individuals together and hoping for the best. It’s about cultivating an environment where trust, open communication, mutual respect, and a shared vision converge.
